title: 108_s2420
content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is an exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage. The paragraph heading is amended to include rules, specifying certain non federally funded coverage for children. A State cannot exclude a child from being considered a targeted vulnerable child if their family's total annual healthcare costs exceed 5%. The Social Security Act is amended to include targeted vulnerable children, particularly those with family income exceeding 200% of the poverty line. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to receive increased federal funding under SCHIP. The limitation on expenditures for outreach strategies is waived for these states. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to receive increased federal funding under SCHIP. The enhanced FMAP for a State for a fiscal year shall be increased by 5 percentage points with respect to outreach expenditures for children under title XIX. Outreach strategies include presumptive eligibility. The State provides presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX and title XIX, eliminating asset tests for children's eligibility. The State allows for automatic renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under title XIX and title XIX if no changes are reported, subject to verification from State databases. Medicaid eligibility under the Social Security Act is amended to include this provision. The State allows for presumptive eligibility for individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance under subsection (a)(10)(A) and title XXI. The State allows presumptive eligibility for individuals under 19 years of age for medical assistance under title XXI, with 12-month continuous eligibility, no asset test, and passive renewal of eligibility. The amendments to the Social Security Act regarding medical assistance for individuals under 19 years of age will take effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to increase funding for SCHIP and eliminates the SCHIP DIP. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 5 imposes limitations on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not used all available allotments. Amendment to the Social Security Act imposes limitations on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not fully expended available allotments for child health assistance. The amendments to the Social Security Act impose limitations on payments to states with enrollment caps that have unspent allotments for child health assistance from prior fiscal years. States are not prohibited from establishing regular open enrollment periods for applications. Effective date of the amendments is October 1, 2004. The Social Security Act amendments apply Medicaid managed care requirements to SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
